docs.lead_paragraph: Manny Ramirez stepped to the plate for his first swing in the first game of the World Series against the St. Louis Cardinals on Saturday night. All the major league big shots, the coaches, the managers, the players in each dugout, were watching to see what Ramirez, the Red Sox slugger, would do. But surely no one at Fenway Park was studying Ramirez with more intensity -- and with more firsthand knowledge of that famous swing -- than a slightly built, middle-aged man in a Red Sox jacket and blue jeans whose highest position in baseball has been Little League coach.
docs.abstract: Carlos Ferreira, who coached Manny Ramirez in Little League in Washington Heights section of Manhattan and has counseled him ever since, is close to Ramirez again as Boston battles St Louis Cardinals in World Series; Ramirez's wife, Juliana, whom Ramirez married only after Ferreira told him, 'She's the one,' says Ferreira loves Manny like a son; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: At the rate the Boston Red Sox are going, they will soon be selling their World Series highlight film, which should be quite a bargain, considering it can double as a bloopers video. In years past, Boston was known as the team haunted by every little mistake. But in this glorious season, even the most egregious gaffe is easily overcome. Get behind by 3-0 to the Yankees in the American League Championship Series? No problem. Make eight errors in the first two games of the World Series? No worries.

docs.lead_paragraph: PARDON me if the subject is still too raw for some to contemplate at this moment, but here's a question about the Curse of the Bambino, a phenomenon that, it seems, came up more than once in the past week. How did it get there? Did the Fates, anonymous cosmic tricksters, put it on the Red Sox in an incredibly mean bit of redundant cruelty, compounding stupidity with eternal damnation? Or did Babe Ruth, whether out of pique at being traded or just plain orneriness, unload an ex post facto bolt of toxic karma on his former mates?

docs.lead_paragraph: The players voted the Boston right-hander Curt Schilling onto the American League All-Star team, and Schilling was sheepish yesterday after his manager, Terry Francona, announced that Schilling would not pitch in the All-Star Game on Tuesday because of a bone bruise in his right ankle. But Joe Torre of the Yankees, who will manage the American League team, said he eased Schilling's mind in a phone conversation. ''Curt was very reluctant to say he wouldn't be able to pitch,'' Torre said. ''We talked, and he was sort of relieved when I told him, 'Your obligation is to your team.' He's been getting treatment on that heel just about every start.''

headline.main: Now You See It, Now You Don't

docs.lead_paragraph: If you missed the home run that Jerry Casale, then a Boston Red Sox pitcher, hit against the Yankees in 1959, he'll be happy to play the radio call for you, as he has for thousands of customers at Pino's, his modest Italian restaurant on 34th Street near Park Avenue. But get there soon: the homer will fade even deeper into the history books next month. Mr. Casale and his wife, Marge, plan to close shop around the turn of the year. ''When we first started over here, I didn't want people to know I was a professional baseball player,'' he said. That, clearly, has changed. An entire wall of the restaurant features a mural of Fenway Park, the scoreboard showing no outs in the bottom of the second, and a younger, lither version of Mr. Casale about to slam that fateful home run over the Green Monster, Fenway's left-field wall.

docs.lead_paragraph: Tom Gordon, the American League's top closer in 1998, had elbow surgery yesterday that is expected to sideline him for the 2000 season, and he has apparently pitched his last game for the Boston Red Sox. Gordon had a tendon transplanted from his left wrist to replace a ligament in his right elbow. The usual recovery period is 12 to 16 months, said Kevin Shea, a Red Sox spokesman.
